name: Discovery Research Proposals
intro: Designing and conducting research to answer questions very early in the development of a product or feature is my favorite part of UX.  I am a sucker for translating the “back of a napkin scratch” into experiments which will actually give us insight into how feasible an idea is, what users actually need in order to achieve our goals and what that solution might look like.

examples.title: CoreTech Website Research Proposal
examples.caption: A formal proposal to conduct a user satisfaction study on a prototype website

examples.title: MyApps Anywhere Research Proposal
examples.caption: Proposed research to determine why adoption of a solution has plateaued

examples.title: NOW Answer Engine Research Proposal
examples.caption: Questions asked to research interview participants for an internal search engine project

name: Discovery Survey Results
intro: How research is presented is just as important, if not even more important and designing how research data will be collected. It is my top priority to make sure results remain relevant to the audience and unbiassed while also conveying the information stakeholders and business leaders need to make informed decisions.

examples.title: Developer Community Research Results
examples.caption: Results from a survey testing a feasibility of an internal developer community

examples.title: Developer Community Research Results
examples.caption: One slider showing the progression from one experiment to the next while researching an internal community

examples.title: NOW Search Engine User Research Results
examples.caption: Results from questions asked to research participants for an internal search engine project

examples.title: Services Health Dashboard Research Readout
examples.caption: Results from questions asked to research participants for an internal cloud services dashboard

name: Competitive Analysis
intro: One of the benefits of LEAN Canvases is that they force you to take a realistic look at your ideas before you bring them to market.  Perhaps the most important part of a LEAN canvas is looking at your product’s competitive advantage.  One way to help establish what that is, is through a competitive analysis of similar products in the marketplace.

examples.title: LinkedIn Lookup Competitive Analysis
examples.caption: An analysis of LinkedIn's Lookup product

name: Personas
intro: For me, personas are a chance for two main things.  One, it is the first chance to translate all of the research data into a living artifact that represents what has been learned about the users so far. Two, it is a chance to bring together all the stakeholders and establish a shared vision for what the user experience should become.

examples.title: GhostRed Personas
examples.caption: Personas for a internal/external recruiting platform

examples.title: Developer Community Personas
examples.caption: Personas for an internal developer community

examples.title: MyApps Anywhere Team Personas
examples.caption: Personas for the team I was apart of when we were trying to decide on our next phase of agile tooling

examples.title: NOW Answer Engine Personas
examples.caption: Personas for an internal search engine project

name: User Stories
intro: Most of the time I do not feel the need to make these a separate artifact and instead include them in personas.  However, sometimes it is necessary to be explicit for the benefit of stakeholders, coworkers or business leaders.

examples.title: NOW Answer Engine User Stories
examples.caption: User stories for an internal search engine product showing what users expect to be able to accomplish

name: High Fidelity Mockups
intro: The next step after stepping away from the whiteboard for the first time, deep interaction mockups are an opportunity for creativity to meet research results to become the first detailed look into the visual aspects of a user experience. This our chance as designers to show our understanding of our users through the experience we create.

examples.title: GhostRed Recruiting Platform Mockup
examples.caption: Deep interaction mock ups with limited responsive design shown for an internal recruiting platform.

examples.title: NOW Answer Engine Mockup
examples.caption: Deep interaction mock ups for a crowd sourced internal search platform.

examples.title: SANDCASTLE Design Suite Mockup
examples.caption: Deep interaction mock ups for an internal “click and drag” website development tool.

examples.title: MyApps Anywhere Website Mockup
examples.caption: Deep interaction mock ups for an internal product web presence.

name: Usability Results
intro: For me, nothing beats one-on-one in-person design assessments where the participant is asked to complete a series of open-ended scenarios.  Aesthetically a website may look great, but its usability can be a completely different story once a user is asked to actually do something with it.

examples.title: NOW Answer Engine A/B Testing Results
examples.caption: Results from an A/B test of two different approaches to an internal search engine project

examples.title: CoreTech Website A/B Testing Results - R1
examples.caption: Results of a test were I created a B design to a preexisting design based on earlier design assessment results

examples.title: SANDCASTLE Design Suite A/B Testing Results
examples.caption: Results from a A/B test for an internal “click and drag” website development tool

name: Scenario Testing
intro: I have seen the benefits of using testing scenarios based on the goals outlined in the personas for a project to test the performance of designs compared to simple “Get It Testing”.  Nothing compares to actually asking users to solve relevant situations using your design and the feedback gained by doing so.

examples.title: MyApps Anywhere Client Dashboard Test
examples.caption: A mock windows desktop used to test out how users interact with a client dashboard to solve application issues

examples.title: GhostRed Booth Test
examples.caption: A mock event recruitment booth to test how potential participants might respond to a game-like experience

name: A/B Tests
intro: My favorite way to start the design process is by creating an A/B test plan that explicitly compares several different conclusions to research results.  Whether it be IA, Flow, Aesthetics or something else, designing and testing to that experiment can provide a wealth of information once design assessments are completed.

examples.title: GhostRed Recruiting Platform Mockup A
examples.caption: Design A for the first iteration design A/B test for an internal/external recruiting platform

examples.title: GhostRed Recruiting Platform Mockup B
examples.caption: Design B for the first iteration design A/B test for an internal/external recruiting platform

examples.title: NOW Answer Engine Mockup A
examples.caption: Design A for the first iteration design A/B test for a crowd sourced internal search platform

examples.title: NOW Answer Engine Mockup B
examples.caption: Design B for the first iteration design A/B test for a crowd sourced internal search platform

name: Developed Websites
intro: My goal when asked to develop a web application is to create easy to understand and expandable code that delivers on the promises made during the design phase.  In the future I would like to focus more on Test Driven Development.

examples.title: Innovation Studio Team Website
examples.caption: Website I designed and develped used to internally market the team I was apart of with GE Digital create with Angular 1, HTML5 and CSS3

examples.title: MyApps Anywhere Site
examples.caption: Developed with Angular 1, HTML5 and CSSw3, this is part of an internal web product web presence I designed and developed

name: Infographics
intro: Infographics create the interesting challenge of conveying lots of information and establishing the desired user perception in a very limited interaction, which is perhaps why I find them so interesting to design.

examples.title: Innovation Studio Accelerator
examples.caption: Infographic for an internal project team accelerator program

examples.title: MyApps Anywhere Infographic
examples.caption: Infographic showing how an application works

name: Graphic Design Work
intro: I am only a self taught graphic designer who enjoys creating graphics to enhance the experience of interacting with web applications.  Graphics also serve as a medium to increase users understanding of concepts, processes and more within an application.

examples.title: Innovation Studio Team Graphic
examples.caption: Team member avatars I created for each person on my team in GE for our internal web presence and agile process

examples.title: GhostRed Capture The Flag
examples.caption: Graphic for the GhostRed Capture the Flag product

examples.caption: Graphic for the GhostRed Hackathon product
